relationship_definition: Current or former spouse, parent, step-parent, child, step-child, grandparent, step-grandparent, grandchild, step-grandchild, any person with whom the defendant has a child in common, present household member, or person who has or had a dating relationship with defendant. NOTE: Household member excludes non-romantic/non-intimate co-residents. Dating relationship means current or former relationship of romantic/intimate nature with expectation of affectionate/sexual involvement.
arrest_policy_notes: Alabama does NOT have mandatory arrest for most DV incidents. Officers have discretion to make warrantless arrests with probable cause. No specific dominant aggressor or primary physical aggressor requirement in statute.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Not specified in statute
primary_statute_citation: Ala. Code § 13A-6-130 (DV First Degree); § 13A-6-131 (DV Second Degree); § 13A-6-132 (DV Third Degree); § 30-5-1 et seq. (Protection from Abuse Act); § 13A-11-72 (Certain persons forbidden to possess firearm)
notable_provisions: Three-tier system: DV 3rd Degree (Class A misdemeanor, up to 1 year jail, $6,000 fine; 2nd conviction requires mandatory 10 days; 3rd conviction is Class C felony with minimum 1 year 1 day). DV 2nd Degree (Class B felony, minimum 2 years, maximum 20 years, $30,000 fine). DV 1st Degree (Class A felony, 10-99 years or life; 2nd conviction requires minimum 1 year). Enhanced penalties: minimum sentence doubles if order violation occurs or if committed in presence of child under 14. Protective orders can require firearm surrender. Conviction results in permanent federal firearm prohibition under 18 U.S.C. 922(g). Strangulation/suffocation treated as enhanced offense.
recent_changes: Ongoing: Alabama has been strengthening DV penalties and protections. 2009: Added law enforcement authority to disarm individuals at scenes. Recent years: Enhanced penalties for repeat offenders and violations in presence of children. Note: Alabama does not have state-level firearm surrender requirements but courts can order surrender as part of protective orders.

relationship_definition: Household members include: adults or minors who are current or former spouses; adults or minors who live together or have lived together; adults or minors who are in or have been in a dating, courtship, or engagement relationship; adults or minors who are related to each other up to fourth degree of consanguinity (whole or half blood, or by adoption); adults or minors related or formerly related by marriage; persons who have a child of the relationship; minors who are children of persons in these relationships.
arrest_policy_notes: Alaska has MANDATORY ARREST. Under AS 18.65.530, officer SHALL arrest without warrant if probable cause to believe person committed DV within previous 12 hours (excludes murder/manslaughter AS 11.41.100-130). Also mandatory for protective order violations and release condition violations. Must determine primary aggressor based on injury severity and prior incidents. Officer may NOT threaten arrest of all parties to discourage intervention requests. If no arrest or dual arrest, must document reasons in writing. Cannot release until court appearance.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare standards for DV cases under AS 18.66.300; continuing education required for public employees
primary_statute_citation: AS 18.65.530 (Mandatory Arrest); AS 18.66.100-180 (Protective Orders); AS 18.66.990 (Definitions); AS 11.41 (Crimes Against Person); AS 12.30.016 (Conditions of Release)
notable_provisions: MANDATORY ARREST within 12-hour window. Assault IV (reckless injury): Class A M (up to 1 year). Assault III (injury with weapon, serious injury): Class C F (up to 5 years). Assault II (serious injury with weapon): Class B F (up to 10 years). Assault I (serious injury with intent): Class A F (up to 99 years). Protective order violation with prior DV: minimum 20 days imprisonment. Emergency protective order: 72 hours (AS 18.66.110). Long-term order: up to 1 year, renewable. Court hearing within 20 days. Central registry of protective orders maintained by DPS. Forfeiture of deadly weapon used in DV crime. Council on Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault oversees programs.
recent_changes: Alaska continues having among strongest mandatory arrest laws in nation. 12-hour arrest window clearly defined. Primary aggressor determination required to prevent dual arrests. Extensive victim notification requirements when defendant released. Batterers intervention programs available. DV fatality review teams established (AS 18.66.400). Ongoing focus on rural Alaska access to services.

relationship_definition: Current or former spouse, parent, step-parent, child, step-child, grandparent, step-grandparent, grandchild, step-grandchild, any person with whom the defendant has a child in common, present household member, or person who has or had a dating relationship with defendant. NOTE: Household member excludes non-romantic/non-intimate co-residents. Dating relationship means current or former relationship of romantic/intimate nature with expectation of affectionate/sexual involvement.
arrest_policy_notes: Alabama does NOT have mandatory arrest for most DV incidents. Officers have discretion to make warrantless arrests with probable cause. No specific dominant aggressor or primary physical aggressor requirement in statute.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Not specified in statute
primary_statute_citation: Ala. Code § 13A-6-130 (DV First Degree); § 13A-6-131 (DV Second Degree); § 13A-6-132 (DV Third Degree); § 30-5-1 et seq. (Protection from Abuse Act); § 13A-11-72 (Certain persons forbidden to possess firearm)
notable_provisions: Three-tier system: DV 3rd Degree (Class A misdemeanor, up to 1 year jail, $6,000 fine; 2nd conviction requires mandatory 10 days; 3rd conviction is Class C felony with minimum 1 year 1 day). DV 2nd Degree (Class B felony, minimum 2 years, maximum 20 years, $30,000 fine). DV 1st Degree (Class A felony, 10-99 years or life; 2nd conviction requires minimum 1 year). Enhanced penalties: minimum sentence doubles if order violation occurs or if committed in presence of child under 14. Protective orders can require firearm surrender. Conviction results in permanent federal firearm prohibition under 18 U.S.C. 922(g). Strangulation/suffocation treated as enhanced offense.
recent_changes: Ongoing: Alabama has been strengthening DV penalties and protections. 2009: Added law enforcement authority to disarm individuals at scenes. Recent years: Enhanced penalties for repeat offenders and violations in presence of children. Note: Alabama does not have state-level firearm surrender requirements but courts can order surrender as part of protective orders.

relationship_definition: Household member includes: current or former spouse, persons living together or formerly living together, parents/children, persons related by blood or marriage, persons who are dating or were dating, persons who have child in common. Very broad definition covering dating relationships and cohabitants.
arrest_policy_notes: Alaska has MANDATORY arrest for DV crimes within previous 12 hours (Alaska Stat. § 18.65.530). Officers MUST arrest with probable cause for any DV crime (felony or misdemeanor) except most serious crimes under AS 11.41.100-130, protective order violations, and release condition violations. Exception: If multiple complaints from same incident, officer evaluates to determine principal physical aggressor and arrests only that person. Officers must document in writing reasons for not arresting or for arresting multiple people.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Not specified in statute
primary_statute_citation: Alaska Stat. § 18.65.530 (Mandatory arrest); § 18.66.100 (Protective orders); § 11.61.200 (Firearm restrictions); Chapter 11.41 (Crimes against the person); § 18.66.110 (Ex parte orders)
notable_provisions: Mandatory arrest within 12 hours of incident with probable cause. Emergency protective orders: up to 72 hours (law enforcement can request by phone when courts closed). Ex parte orders: up to 20 days. Final orders: up to 1 year, renewable. Firearm restrictions: Court may prohibit use/possession of deadly weapons if weapon possessed or used during DV. Court may order surrender of firearms if firearm possessed or used. Officers may seize weapons at scene if in plain view or if weapon possessed/used. Alaska has NO state-level prohibition on firearm possession for misdemeanor DV convictions (federal law applies). Protective orders effective anywhere in US under federal law. Central registry maintained by Department of Public Safety.
recent_changes: 2025: Proposed Gun Violence Protective Order (red flag) legislation (HB162) - not yet enacted. Would allow 20-day ex parte orders with 24-hour firearm surrender requirement. Recent years: Strengthened mandatory arrest provisions and protective order enforcement. Alaska has maintained strong mandatory arrest policy since 1990s reforms.

relationship_definition: Spouses or former spouses; persons residing or having resided in same household; persons with child in common; victim or defendant pregnant by other party; relatives by blood or court order (parent, grandparent, child, grandchild, brother, sister) or by marriage (in-laws, step-relations); child who resides or resided in same household as defendant and is related by blood to former spouse or household member; persons currently or previously in romantic or sexual relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: AZ has MANDATORY arrest for DV involving physical injury or use/threatening exhibition of deadly weapon/dangerous instrument (A.R.S. § 13-3601(B)). Officers MUST arrest persons 15+ with probable cause unless reasonable grounds exist that victim will be protected from further injury. For non-physical DV offenses, arrest is discretionary. Officers may arrest both parties ONLY if probable cause exists that both independently committed DV. Officers may temporarily seize firearms if in plain view or found via consent search and officer reasonably believes firearm exposes victim/household to risk of serious injury/death. Firearm held minimum 72 hours.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Not specified in statute
primary_statute_citation: A.R.S. § 13-3601 (DV definition, arrest procedures, weapon seizure); § 13-3602 (Protective orders); § 13-2810 (Interfering with judicial proceedings - violation penalty); § 13-3101(A)(7)(d) (Firearm prohibitions post-conviction)
notable_provisions: DV is not standalone crime but designation added to underlying offenses. All charges involving DV must be designated by letters "DV". Aggravated DV (A.R.S. § 13-3601.02): Third offense within 84 months is Class 5 felony even if underlying offense is misdemeanor. Mandatory jail: 4 months minimum for third offense (two priors), 8 months minimum for fourth+ offense (three+ priors). Penalties: Underlying crime determines base penalty; mandatory DV counseling program (26-52 sessions); up to 2 years added for pregnant victim if defendant knew. Protective orders: Emergency up to 72+ hours, final up to 1 year. Firearm prohibition if court finds credible threat. Must surrender firearms within 24 hours of service. Defendant can request hearing within 10 days. Federal Lautenberg Amendment applies (lifetime ban for DV misdemeanor convictions). Officers seize weapons at scene if risk exists.
recent_changes: 2019: Enhanced firearm restrictions and surrender procedures in protective orders. Recent: Address Confidentiality Program expanded for DV victims. Ongoing: AZ courts implementing improved firearm surrender tracking systems. Note: DV designation causes loss of gun rights even for misdemeanor convictions due to federal law.

relationship_definition: Spouses, former spouses, parents and children, persons related by blood within fourth degree, any children residing in household, persons who presently or in past have resided or cohabitated together, persons who have had child in common, persons who are or have been in dating relationship (requires degree of commitment beyond casual acquaintances).
arrest_policy_notes: AR has MANDATORY arrest for felony DV (Ark. Code § 16-81-113). For misdemeanors, arrest is "preferred response" but not strictly mandatory. Officers may arrest without warrant when probable cause exists that defendant violated protective order or committed domestic abuse. Officer does not need to witness abuse to make arrest. Officers must identify primary aggressor in cases with dual complaints to avoid dual arrests. Before release on bail, judge must consider defendant history of violence and safety risk. Judge may set conditions prohibiting victim contact and dangerous weapon possession. 24-hour cooling off period typical after arrest.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare professionals must report suspected DV to Dept of Human Services within 24 hours (Ark. Code § 12-18-109)
primary_statute_citation: Ark. Code § 5-26-303 to 309 (Domestic battering); § 9-15-201 et seq. (Domestic Abuse Act - Protective orders); § 16-81-113 (Warrantless arrest); § 5-73-103 (Firearm restrictions); § 9-13-101 (Child custody limitations)
notable_provisions: Three-tier battering system: 3rd degree (Class A misdemeanor, up to 1 year jail, $2,500 fine; purposely/recklessly causing physical injury); 2nd degree (Class B felony, 5-20 years, $15,000 fine; causing serious physical injuries); 1st degree (Class B or Y felony, 10-40 years; permanent disfigurement/disability or serious injury to child under 5 with extreme indifference). Enhanced penalties: Third offense of 3rd degree within 10 years becomes 1st degree (Class B felony). Mandatory 60 days jail for second offense within 5 years (may suspend 40 days). Pregnant victim enhancements. Child presence enhancements. Protective orders: Temporary ex parte up to 30 days, final orders 90 days to 10 years (court decides duration). Violations: First (Class A misdemeanor, up to 1 year, $1,000 fine); subsequent within 5 years (Class D felony, up to 6 years, $10,000 fine). Firearm violation of order provisions (Class D felony). Court may order GPS tracking 4-12 months. Federal and state firearm prohibitions apply during order. Mandatory DV treatment program for convictions.
recent_changes: Recent years: Enhanced penalties for repeat offenders and violations in presence of children. AR has been strengthening DV protections. 2024: Discussions about improving mandatory arrest policies and post-arrest procedures. Note: Academic research suggests AR should adopt stricter mandatory arrest and prosecution policies. Current "preferred response" for misdemeanors criticized as inadequate compared to true mandatory arrest states.

relationship_definition: Spouses/former spouses; domestic partners; persons with whom defendant has/had child in common; persons who live together/lived together (cohabitants); persons currently/previously in dating relationship; relatives by blood or court order (parent, grandparent, child, grandchild, brother, sister) or by marriage (in-laws, step-relations); child who resides/resided in same household and is related by blood to former spouse/household member. NOTE: Very broad definition including dating partners (romantic or intimate relationship beyond casual dating).
arrest_policy_notes: CA has MANDATORY arrest for DV with probable cause (Cal. Penal Code § 13701). Officers MUST arrest if probable cause exists that person abused spouse, partner, ex-spouse, or family member. Officers shall identify and arrest dominant aggressor (most significant, not first aggressor). Policy discourages but does not prohibit dual arrests. Officers consider: intent of law to protect victims, history of DV between parties, self-defense claims, fear levels, comparative injuries, threat likelihood. Enacted 1986 to protect victims. Criticism exists that policy sometimes results in victims being arrested. Once arrest made, case proceeds regardless of victim wishes.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Not specified in statute
primary_statute_citation: Cal. Penal Code § 273.5 (Corporal injury to spouse/cohabitant); § 243(e)(1) (Domestic battery); § 13700-13730 (Law enforcement response); § 6200 et seq. (Domestic Violence Prevention Act - protective orders); § 29825 (Firearm restrictions post-conviction)
notable_provisions: DV not standalone crime but designation added to underlying offenses. All charges with DV designated by "DV" on record. Corporal injury (§273.5): Wobbler, misdemeanor (up to 1 year, $6,000 fine, likely 30-day minimum) or felony (2-4 years prison, $6,000 fine, minimum 30 days; additional 3-5 years if serious injury). Domestic battery (§243(e)(1)): Misdemeanor (up to 1 year, $2,000 fine). Statute of limitations: 7 years for all DV offenses (extended from 5 years in 2024; previously 1 year misdemeanor/3 years felony before 2020 SB 273). Firearm restrictions: Conviction §273.5 results in LIFETIME ban. Most other DV misdemeanors: 10-year CA ban, but lifetime federal ban if qualifies as MCDV. All felony convictions result in lifetime firearm ban. 2020: Added "coercive control" as DV category (control of movements, communications, finances, access to services). Protective orders: Emergency (72+ hours), temporary, permanent (indefinite unless modified). Mandatory DV counseling (26-52 sessions). Address Confidentiality Program available.
recent_changes: 2024: Extended statute of limitations from 5 to 7 years. Multiple bills signed 9/27/24: improved restraining order access, financial abuse protections, domestic homicide investigation tools, digital tracking prevention. 2020 (SB 273): Extended statute of limitations to 5 years, created "coercive control" category. 2019: Enhanced firearm restrictions and surrender procedures in protective orders. Recent: Strengthened protections for financial abuse, improved tracking of domestic violence-related deaths. CA continues expanding DV protections and victim support programs.

relationship_definition: Spouses, former spouses, past or present unmarried couples, persons who are both parents of same child regardless of whether married or lived together at any time. NOTE: Intimate relationship definition narrower than many states - roommates and friends NOT covered unless meet above criteria. Dating relationship covered if past or present unmarried couple.
arrest_policy_notes: CO has MANDATORY arrest for DV with probable cause (various sources indicate mandatory policy). Officers MUST arrest if probable cause exists DV crime occurred. Officers use five criteria to determine legitimacy: revenge, control, coercion, intimidation, punishment. If officer believes one or more criteria met, legally required to arrest suspect. Policy intended to provide resources to protect DV victims but criticized for creating ambiguities leading to numerous wrongful arrests. Near-automatic arrest policy in practice. Officers have duty to identify situation but limited discretion once probable cause established.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Not specified in statute
primary_statute_citation: C.R.S. § 18-6-800.3 (Definitions); § 18-6-801 (Sentencing); § 18-6-803.5 (Violation of protection order); § 13-14-105.5 (Firearm relinquishment protective orders); § 13-14.5-101 et seq. (Extreme Risk Protection Orders); § 18-1-1001 (Mandatory protection orders criminal cases)
notable_provisions: DV is NOT standalone crime but sentence enhancer applied to underlying criminal charges. Treatment evaluation and program required for conviction. Habitual DV offender: Misdemeanor with 3 prior DV convictions becomes Class 5 felony. Statute of limitations: Criminal - 18 months misdemeanors, 3 years felonies; up to 20 years for sexual assault/child sexual abuse; no limit for rape reported within 20 years with DNA. Civil suits: 6 years general, no limit for sexual misconduct. Protective orders: Emergency, temporary (up to 14 days), permanent (can last indefinitely unless modified; restrained person must wait 2 years to file motion to remove). Firearm restrictions: Court must order prohibition and surrender if protection order involves physical force/threat. Surrender: 24 hours if in courtroom, 48 hours if not (excludes weekends/holidays). Options: sell to licensed dealer, store with law enforcement, transfer to eligible relative (antiques/curios only). Extreme Risk Protection Orders (2019): Family/law enforcement can petition; temporary up to 14 days, full ERPO up to 364 days renewable. Violation of firearm provisions: misdemeanor (up to 364 days, $1,000). Federal Lautenberg Amendment applies.
recent_changes: 2023 (SB23-170): Updated ERPO law. 2022: Federal Bipartisan Safer Communities Act expanded DV firearm prohibitions to unmarried dating partners. 2021: Domestic abuse task force created to develop statutory definition for Children's Code recognizing impact on child emotional/developmental wellbeing. 2019 (HB19-1177): Extreme Risk Protection Orders (red flag law) implemented 1/1/2020. 2018: Extended statute of limitations for DV-related assault/stalking from 1 year to 6 years; 20 years if victim disabled/handicapped. 2025: Automated notification system adopted for protective orders to notify protected persons when restrained person applies for/denied/completes firearm purchase. Over half of CO counties (37/64) declared 2A Sanctuary status stating non-enforcement of ERPO law (controversial).

relationship_definition: Spouses, former spouses, parents, persons 18+ related by blood or marriage, persons 16+ (except platonic roommates per 2019 clarification) living together or who have lived together, persons with child in common, persons currently or previously in dating relationship. NOTE: 2019 PA 19-189 clarified mandatory arrest carve-out applies ONLY to non-family platonic roommates in campus housing or rental agreements.
arrest_policy_notes: CT has MANDATORY arrest for family violence crimes (C.G.S. § 46b-38b). Officers MUST arrest when they determine upon speedy information that family violence crime has been committed. Officers must identify and arrest DOMINANT AGGRESSOR (person who poses most serious ongoing threat). Policy discourages but does NOT prohibit dual arrests. Officers consider: need to protect victims, self-defense claims, relative degree of injury, threats creating fear, history of family violence between parties. Officers may submit report to state attorney for non-dominant party. Enacted 1986 after Thurman v. City of Torrington.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Not specified in statute
primary_statute_citation: C.G.S. § 46b-38a (Definitions); § 46b-38b (Arrest policies/dominant aggressor); § 46b-15 (Relief from abuse - protective orders); § 46b-1 (Civil definition including coercive control - family relations matters only)
notable_provisions: Family violence NOT separate criminal offense - various crimes can be charged as family violence if committed against family/household member. Criminal definition: incident resulting in physical harm, bodily injury, assault, or threatened violence creating fear of imminent harm (includes stalking, pattern of threatening). Verbal abuse NOT family violence unless present danger and likelihood physical violence will occur. Civil definition (family relations matters ONLY - restraining orders, divorce, custody): includes physical violence, stalking, threatening, AND COERCIVE CONTROL (Jennifer's Law 2021). Coercive control: pattern unreasonably interfering with free will/liberty including isolation, deprivation, controlling movements/communications/finances, threatening cruelty to animals. Penalties vary by underlying offense: 2nd-degree stalking/threatening (Class A misdemeanor, 1 year, $2,000); 1st-degree assault (Class B felony, 20-25 years, $15-20,000; Class A felony if terminates pregnancy). Restraining orders: 90-day initial (can be extended indefinitely). Address Confidentiality Program available. Arrest records must redact victim name/address (cannot appear in police blotter). Mandatory next-day arraignment. Federal and state firearm prohibitions apply.
recent_changes: 2021 (SB-1091 "Jennifer's Law"): Added coercive control to civil DV definition for family relations matters. Named after Jennifer Dulos (disappeared 2019, believed murdered by estranged husband). 2019 (PA 19-189): Clarified mandatory arrest carve-out applies ONLY to non-family platonic roommates in specified living situations. 2018: Added carve-out for platonic roommates. 1986: Family Violence Act enacted in response to Thurman v. City of Torrington (1984 federal court decision holding city violated Equal Protection when police failed to protect spousal abuse victim). CT among 14 states + DC with mandatory arrest as of 1994; now one of 27 states with mandatory arrest and dominant aggressor provisions. Studies show only 14% of arrested offenders prosecuted/convicted; "nolled" decision usual outcome.

relationship_definition: Spouses, former spouses, sexual or intimate partners, persons living together or formerly living together, parents and children (including step and in-laws), siblings, grandparents and grandchildren, persons in substantive dating relationship, persons with child in common. Broad definition including dating relationships requiring degree of commitment.
arrest_policy_notes: DE has DISCRETIONARY/PRO-ARREST policy (Del. Code tit. 11 § 1904). Officers MAY arrest without warrant when reasonable grounds exist that misdemeanor involving physical injury/threat or illegal sexual contact/attempted sexual contact occurred. MANDATORY arrest ONLY for violations of PFA or protective orders. Before release, police must bring suspect before judge for bail/conditions. Cash bail required for DV offenses. State policy says offender "should" be arrested for felonies; misdemeanors are pro-arrest but not strictly mandatory. DE among minority of states without full mandatory arrest.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Not specified in statute
primary_statute_citation: Del. Code tit. 10 § 1024 (First offenders diversion); § 1041 (DV definitions); § 1044 (Firearm surrender); § 1045 (Firearm restrictions); § 1046 (Arrest/bail requirements); tit. 11 § 1904 (Warrantless arrest authority); tit. 13 § 705A (Rebuttable presumption against custody)
notable_provisions: DV NOT separate crime - various crimes can be DV offenses when committed against protected persons. Common DV-related offenses: assault, terroristic threats, harassment, strangulation, offensive touching, stalking, reckless endangering, menacing. First-time offenders eligible for diversion: plead guilty, court defers judgment, 1-year probation with DVCC-certified treatment program completion. Successful completion: discharge/dismissal (plea still counts as prior DV offense). Protective order violation: criminal contempt, Class A misdemeanor unless defendant injured victim or used/threatened deadly weapon/firearm (Class F felony, mandatory minimum 15 days jail). Cash bail required for pretrial release on DV charges. Firearm restrictions: conviction of any felony or misdemeanor DV OR subject to protective order = prohibited from possessing firearms. Violation: Class D felony (Class C if prior convictions). Federal prohibitions also apply. Child custody: rebuttable presumption AGAINST custody/residence to DV perpetrator unless completed treatment, demonstrated rehabilitation, no further acts. If child subjected to death/near death injuries by perpetrator: court shall not award custody/visitation without expert testimony arrangement is in child's best interests. Conviction stays on record for life with few exceptions. May result in Child Protection Registry placement (loss of healthcare/childcare/education employment).
recent_changes: 2016 (HB 373 with HA 2): Transferred misdemeanor DV criminal jurisdiction between former spouses, couples with child in common, cohabitating couples from Court of Common Pleas to Family Court. 2016 (SB 220 with SA 1): Amended DVCC statute, expanded Fatal Incident Review Team, clarified near death definition. 2016 (SB 209): Required DVCC-certified treatment providers for first offenders program. 2008 (HB 486): Added $15 fee on marriage certificates to fund DV programs. 1999 (HB 161 "Firearms Bill"): Made it illegal for PFA respondents to purchase/possess firearms during order duration; persons convicted of limited category of DV misdemeanors "persons prohibited" for 5 years from conviction date. 1994 (SB 351 "Child Protection from Domestic Violence Act"): Required Family Court judges consider DV evidence in custody/visitation determinations. 1993 (SB 184): Established Protection from Abuse statute. DE has comprehensive framework but discretionary arrest policy distinguishes it from mandatory arrest states.

relationship_definition: Family or household member means spouses, former spouses, persons related by blood or marriage, persons who are presently residing together as if a family or who have resided together in the past as if a family, and persons who are parents of a child in common regardless of whether they have been married. With the exception of persons who have a child in common, the family or household members must be currently residing or have in the past resided together in the same single dwelling unit. Dating partners who do not live together are NOT covered under domestic violence statutes but may seek dating violence injunctions under separate provisions.
arrest_policy_notes: Florida does NOT have mandatory arrest for most DV crimes. Officers have discretion and MAY arrest without a warrant if they have probable cause that domestic or dating violence occurred. Mandatory arrest applies ONLY for violations of protective orders/restraining orders, where the person must be held for at least 36 hours. When two or more persons make complaints, officers must determine the primary aggressor. Defendants arrested on DV charges cannot be released until appearing before a judge.
mandatory_reporter_categories: No specific mandatory reporting for adult domestic violence. General mandatory reporting exists for child abuse and elder abuse.
primary_statute_citation: Florida Statutes Chapter 741.28-741.31 (Domestic Violence); Fla. Stat. § 784.046 (Dating Violence Injunctions); Fla. Stat. § 741.30 (Injunctions for Protection Against Domestic Violence); Fla. Stat. § 741.283 (Mandatory Minimum Sentences)
notable_provisions: Mandatory 26-29 week Batterer's Intervention Program (BIP) for convictions. Lethality assessment required by law enforcement during DV investigations. No-drop prosecution policy - victims cannot unilaterally drop charges. DV convictions cannot be sealed or expunged. First-degree misdemeanor DV battery: up to 1 year jail, $1,000 fine. Mandatory minimums: 5 days if bodily injury with adjudication; 10 days for 2nd offense; 20 days for 3rd+ offense. Second or subsequent DV battery becomes third-degree felony (1-5 years prison, $5,000 fine). Protective order violations: 1st/2nd violation = first-degree misdemeanor (up to 1 year jail, $1,000 fine); 3rd+ violation = third-degree felony (up to 5 years prison, $5,000 fine). Final injunctions can be permanent/indefinite. Address Confidentiality Program available (Fla. Stat. § 741.465). Officers must provide victims with Legal Rights and Remedies Notice.
recent_changes: 2025: Continued emphasis on lethality assessments and enhanced victim protections through strengthened injunction provisions and firearm restrictions. Florida maintains aggressive prosecution standards with no-drop policies and mandatory intervention programs for offenders.

relationship_definition: Family violence means the occurrence of qualifying acts between past or present spouses, persons who are parents of the same child, parents and children, stepparents and stepchildren, foster parents and foster children, or other persons living or formerly living in the same household. Dating partners are covered ONLY if they currently or formerly lived together; dating partners who never lived together are NOT covered. Family violence does not include reasonable discipline administered by a parent to a child in the form of corporal punishment, restraint, or detention.
arrest_policy_notes: Georgia does NOT have mandatory arrest for most family violence crimes. Officers have discretion and MAY arrest without a warrant based on probable cause that family violence occurred or a protective order was violated. When multiple persons make complaints, officers must determine who was the principal physical aggressor. 24-hour cooling-off period before bail consideration for family violence offenses (O.C.G.A. § 17-6-1). Officers must complete written reports documenting all incidents. Some departments may have internal policies requiring arrest.
mandatory_reporter_categories: No specific mandatory reporting for adult domestic violence. General mandatory reporting exists for child abuse and elder abuse.
primary_statute_citation: O.C.G.A. § 19-13-1 (Family Violence Definition); O.C.G.A. §§ 19-13-1 through 19-13-6 (Family Violence Protective Orders); O.C.G.A. § 16-5-23.1 (Battery); O.C.G.A. § 16-5-20 (Assault); O.C.G.A. § 17-4-20.1 (Investigation and Arrests)
notable_provisions: Georgia uses term "family violence" instead of "domestic violence". First conviction of family violence battery is misdemeanor (up to 12 months jail, $1,000 fine); second conviction (against same OR different victim) automatically becomes felony (1-5 years prison). Simple assault/battery involving family violence charged as "misdemeanors of a high and aggravated nature" with enhanced penalties. Aggravated assault/battery involving family violence: 3-20 years prison. Protective order violations: up to 12 months jail, $1,000 fine. Stalking in violation of protective order becomes aggravated stalking (up to 10 years prison, $10,000 fine). Mandatory completion of batterer's intervention programs typical. 24-hour cooling-off period before bail. Vertical prosecution preferred. Firearm restrictions under O.C.G.A. § 16-11-131; violation can result in up to 10 years imprisonment. Protective orders: 12 months standard, can extend to 3 years or permanent. Ex parte orders available. Victim notification of defendant release and bail hearings in certain cases.
recent_changes: 2025: Georgia continues enforcement of family violence statutes with enhanced penalties for repeat offenders. Strong protective order provisions remain in effect with firearm surrender requirements and comprehensive victim protections.

relationship_definition: Family or household member means spouses or reciprocal beneficiaries, former spouses or reciprocal beneficiaries, persons in a dating relationship (romantic courtship or engagement relationship characterized by actions of intimate or sexual nature, excluding casual acquaintanceship or ordinary fraternization in business/social context), persons who have a child in common, parents, children, persons related by consanguinity (blood relation), and persons jointly residing or formerly residing in the same dwelling unit. Does NOT include those who are/were adult roommates or cohabitants only by virtue of an economic or contractual affiliation.
arrest_policy_notes: Hawaii does NOT have mandatory arrest for most DV offenses. Officers MAY arrest without warrant if they have reasonable grounds to believe a person is physically abusing or has physically abused a family or household member. Officers must determine the dominant aggressor in incidents with multiple complaints. Police must order 48-hour cooling-off period (no contact order) if reasonable grounds exist that victim is in probable danger of further abuse. Refusal to leave or contact during cooling-off period results in mandatory arrest.
mandatory_reporter_categories: No specific mandatory reporting for adult domestic violence. General mandatory reporting exists for child abuse.
primary_statute_citation: Hawaii Revised Statutes § 709-906 (Abuse of Family or Household Members); HRS Chapter 586 (Domestic Abuse Protective Orders); HRS § 586-1 (Definitions); HRS § 586-3 (Order for Protection); HRS § 586-11 (Violation of Order for Protection)
notable_provisions: Hawaii uses tiered offense system: Physical abuse is misdemeanor; offensive contact/coercive control is petty misdemeanor (up to 30 days jail). First offense physical abuse: mandatory minimum 48 hours jail. Second/subsequent offense within 1 year: misdemeanor with mandatory minimum 30 days jail (but recent 2020 pilot changed this to eliminate specific time frames). Third offense within 2 years of second conviction: Class C felony (up to 5 years prison). Strangulation: Class C felony (up to 5 years). DV in presence of minor under 14: Class C felony. Mandatory domestic violence intervention or anger management course required. Lethality Assessment Program (LAP) used by law enforcement. 48-hour no-contact cooling-off period when danger exists. Reciprocal beneficiaries (similar to domestic partnerships) included in definitions. Protection order violation: misdemeanor with mandatory minimums (48 hours for first domestic abuse violation, 30 days for second, 48 hours to 10 days for third depending on nature). Court may grant deferred acceptance of guilty plea for misdemeanor/petty misdemeanor offenses under certain conditions. Failure to complete intervention revokes deferral.
recent_changes: 2020: Pilot project established creating petty misdemeanor tier for offensive contact/coercive control and adjusting sentencing structure to reduce court backlog. 2013: Dating relationships added to family/household member definition; cooling-off period increased from 24 to 48 hours. Hawaii recognizes domestic violence as "public health epidemic" in legislative findings.

relationship_definition: Domestic violence means physical injury, sexual abuse, forced imprisonment, or threat thereof of family or household member, or person in dating relationship. "Family member" means spouses, former spouses, persons related by blood, adoption, or marriage. "Household member" means persons who reside or have resided together, and persons who have a child in common regardless of whether they have been married or lived together. "Dating relationship" means social relationship of romantic nature (factors: nature of relationship, length of time, frequency of interaction). Covers both adults and minors in dating relationships.
arrest_policy_notes: Idaho HAS mandatory arrest for domestic violence. Under Idaho Code § 39-6316, officers MUST arrest the alleged perpetrator if there is probable cause to believe domestic assault or battery occurred, even if victim does not wish to press charges. Officers must determine the dominant aggressor when evaluating incidents. This mandatory arrest policy is designed to protect victims and prevent further violence.
mandatory_reporter_categories: No specific mandatory reporting for adult domestic violence. General mandatory reporting exists for child abuse.
primary_statute_citation: Idaho Code § 18-918 (Domestic Violence/Domestic Battery); Idaho Code § 39-6303 (Definitions); Idaho Code Title 39, Chapter 63 (Domestic Violence Crime Prevention Act); Idaho Code § 39-6304 (Protection Orders); Idaho Code § 18-923 (Attempted Strangulation)
notable_provisions: Misdemeanor domestic assault/battery (no traumatic injury): First offense up to 6 months jail, $1,000 fine; Second offense within 10 years up to 1 year jail, $2,000 fine; Third offense within 15 years becomes felony (up to 5 years prison, $5,000 fine). Felony domestic battery (with traumatic injury - defined as ANY wound, injury, or pain whether internal/external, including bruising): up to 10 years prison, $10,000 fine. "Traumatic injury" defined broadly to include even minor harm like bruising or pain. DV in presence of child under 16 DOUBLES all penalties. Attempted strangulation: felony, up to 15 years prison. Persistent felony violator ("three strikes"): Third felony conviction triggers mandatory minimum 5 years, up to life in prison. Prior felony DV conviction + new misdemeanor DV = felony (up to 10 years, $10,000). Mandatory evaluation and counseling/treatment required at defendant's expense. Protection order violations carry same escalating penalties as DV crimes. Legislature declares DV is "serious crime against society" and official response "shall stress enforcement of laws to protect victim." Courts instructed to construe DV laws liberally to promote victim protection.
recent_changes: 2025: Data current. Idaho maintains strong mandatory arrest policy and broad definition of traumatic injury that allows felony charges for relatively minor physical contact. Enhanced penalties for repeat offenders and presence of children remain in effect.

relationship_definition: Family or household members include spouses, former spouses, parents, children, stepchildren, persons related by blood or marriage, persons who share or formerly shared a common dwelling, persons who have a child in common, persons in dating or engagement relationships, and caregivers.
arrest_policy_notes: Police must take all reasonable steps to prevent further abuse. Mandatory arrest for protective order violations.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, school personnel, child care workers, law enforcement
primary_statute_citation: 750 ILCS 60 - Illinois Domestic Violence Act of 1986
notable_provisions: Hope Card program launched 2024 for easy protective order verification. Three types of orders: Emergency (14-21 days), Interim (30 days), Plenary (up to 2 years).
recent_changes: 2024: Hope Card program implemented for protective order verification

relationship_definition: Family or household members and current or former dating partners. Dating relationship means social relationship of romantic nature.
arrest_policy_notes: Mandatory arrest when officer has probable cause to believe domestic violence crime occurred.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, school personnel, law enforcement
notable_provisions: Firearm prohibition for 5 years after misdemeanor DV conviction. Aggravated domestic battery (strangulation) is severity level 7 person felony.
recent_changes: 2018: Enacted firearm restrictions for DV misdemeanor convictions and protective orders

relationship_definition: Family members include spouses, former spouses, parents, grandparents, stepchildren, children. Members of unmarried couple who currently or formerly lived together.
arrest_policy_notes: Mandatory arrest only for protective order violations. No mandatory arrest for initial offense.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, school personnel, social workers
notable_provisions: Fourth degree assault is Class A misdemeanor. Third offense within 5 years becomes Class D felony. EPO valid up to 14 days, DVO up to 3 years.

relationship_definition: Household members and dating partners. Dating partner includes any person in or formerly in intimate or sexual relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Mandatory arrest for protective order violations. Must identify predominant aggressor in conflicting accounts.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, mental health counselors, teachers, clergy
notable_provisions: Gwen's Law (2017): Bail hearing required before release. 48 hours minimum jail for first offense. Enhanced penalties for strangulation, child endangerment, pregnancy.
recent_changes: 2017: Gwen's Law enacted requiring bail hearings for DV arrestees

relationship_definition: Family or household members including spouses, former spouses, individuals living together, parents of same child, minor children of parent/guardian when perpetrator is adult household member, dating partners.
arrest_policy_notes: Mandatory arrest in certain domestic violence situations. Warrantless arrest permitted on probable cause for protection order violations.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, counselors, clergy, law enforcement
primary_statute_citation: Me. Rev. Stat. tit. 17-A, §§ 207-A to 211-A; tit. 19-A, § 4001 et seq.
notable_provisions: Class D misdemeanor (364 days, $2000) for first offense. Class C felony (5 years, $5000) for repeat offenses. Same protection order process for DV, rape, stalking.

relationship_definition: Person eligible for relief includes spouse, former spouse, cohabitant, former cohabitant, person related by blood/marriage, parent, stepparent, child, person with child in common, vulnerable adult.
arrest_policy_notes: Mandatory arrest for protective order violations. May arrest without warrant for stalking or DV with injuries.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, law enforcement
primary_statute_citation: Md. Code, Fam. Law §§ 4-501 to 4-516
notable_provisions: No standalone DV crime - offenses flagged as domestically related. Three order types: interim, temporary (7 days to hearing), final (1-2 years). Violation: 90 days/$1000 first, 1 year/$2500 subsequent.

relationship_definition: Family or household members include those married, formerly married, have a child in common, in substantive dating relationship, related by blood or marriage, or living together.
arrest_policy_notes: Preferred response is arrest for family offenses. Mandatory arrest for abuse prevention order violations. 6-hour minimum hold before bail.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, counselors, clergy, social workers
primary_statute_citation: M.G.L. c. 209A
notable_provisions: Coercive control added to abuse definition September 2024. 209A orders can last up to 1 year with extensions. Violation is up to 2.5 years and $5000 fine.
recent_changes: 2024: Coercive control law enacted expanding definition of abuse. Revenge porn criminalized.

relationship_definition: Spouse, former spouse, individual with child in common, resident or former resident of same household, person in dating relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Officer shall arrest if probable cause to believe assault or assault and battery against spouse, former spouse, dating relationship, household member.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, clergy, law enforcement
notable_provisions: First offense misdemeanor (93 days). Second offense within 7 years is 1 year misdemeanor. Third offense is 5 year felony. PPO valid for at least 182 days.

relationship_definition: Family or household members include spouses, former spouses, parents and children, blood relatives, persons living together or who lived together, persons with a child in common, involved in significant romantic or sexual relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Officer may arrest without warrant if probable cause for domestic assault. Must identify predominant aggressor.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, clergy, law enforcement
notable_provisions: Strangulation is automatic felony (3 years). OFP and DANCO (Domestic Abuse No Contact Order) available. Minimum 10 days jail for gross misdemeanor DV with prior.
recent_changes: 2024: Updated protective order procedures for electronic/Zoom hearings

relationship_definition: Spouses, former spouses, persons living as spouses, other persons related by consanguinity or affinity, parent and child, and persons in dating relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Officer may make warrantless arrest when probable cause to believe domestic violence occurred within past 24 hours.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers
primary_statute_citation: Miss. Code Ann. § 93-21-1 et seq., § 97-3-7
notable_provisions: Simple domestic violence is misdemeanor (up to $500 fine, 6 months jail). Aggravated is felony (up to 5 years). Third conviction becomes felony.

relationship_definition: Family or household members include spouses, former spouses, adults related by blood or marriage, adults who are or have resided together, an adult who is or was in continuing social relationship of romantic or intimate nature, anyone with child in common.
arrest_policy_notes: Officer shall arrest if probable cause that person committed assault or battery against family/household member and person poses continuing danger.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, clergy, law enforcement
primary_statute_citation: Mo. Rev. Stat. § 455.010 et seq., § 565.074
notable_provisions: Fourth degree domestic assault is Class A misdemeanor. Third offense becomes Class E felony. Full order of protection lasts 180 days to 1 year.

relationship_definition: Partners means spouses, former spouses, persons who have a child in common, or persons who have been or are in dating or intimate relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Officer shall arrest if probable cause to believe partner or family member assault occurred. Must identify primary aggressor.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, clergy
primary_statute_citation: Mont. Code Ann. § 45-5-206, § 40-15-101 et seq.
notable_provisions: Partner or family member assault: First offense misdemeanor (up to 1 year, $1000). Second within 5 years or third regardless is felony (up to 5 years).

relationship_definition: Household members includes spouse, former spouse, persons who have a child in common, persons living together or who have lived together, persons related by blood or marriage.
arrest_policy_notes: Officer shall arrest without warrant if probable cause to believe domestic assault has been committed within preceding 12 hours.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, law enforcement
primary_statute_citation: Neb. Rev. Stat. § 28-323, § 42-924 et seq.
notable_provisions: Third degree domestic assault (Class I misdemeanor - 1 year). Second degree is Class IIIA felony. First degree is Class IIA felony (up to 20 years).

relationship_definition: Relationship includes spouses, former spouses, any other person related by blood or marriage, persons cohabiting or who have cohabited, persons in dating relationship, persons with child in common, custodian of victim.
arrest_policy_notes: Primary aggressor must be identified. Mandatory arrest if officer has probable cause.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, clergy, law enforcement
primary_statute_citation: NRS 33.017 et seq., NRS 200.485
notable_provisions: First offense: 2 days to 6 months, weekly counseling. Second within 7 years: 10 days to 6 months. Third becomes Category C felony (1-5 years).

relationship_definition: Family or household member means spouse, former spouse, person cohabiting, person who cohabited, parent, other adult related by blood or affinity, adult in intimate relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Mandatory arrest when probable cause to believe abuse occurred. Must identify primary physical aggressor.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, clergy, law enforcement
primary_statute_citation: RSA 173-B, RSA 631:2-b
notable_provisions: Domestic violence specific offense (RSA 631:2-b). Strangulation is Class B felony. Permanent protective orders available after final hearing.

relationship_definition: Victim includes any person who is 18 or older, an emancipated minor, or who has been in a dating relationship, in a household, related by blood, or has a child in common.
arrest_policy_notes: Mandatory arrest when officer has probable cause to believe domestic violence occurred.
mandatory_reporter_categories: None specified - NJ abolished mandatory reporting for DV
primary_statute_citation: N.J.S.A. 2C:25-17 et seq.
notable_provisions: Prevention of Domestic Violence Act. Charges based on underlying offense (assault, terroristic threats, etc.). Permanent final restraining orders available.

relationship_definition: Household member includes spouse, former spouse, parent, present or former stepparent, present or former parent in law, grandparent, grandchild, co-parent, person with whom petitioner has had continuing personal relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Officer shall arrest without warrant if probable cause that person committed battery against household member.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, clergy
notable_provisions: Battery against household member: petty misdemeanor (up to 6 months). Fourth offense becomes fourth degree felony (up to 18 months). Minimum 72 hours jail for repeat offenses.

relationship_definition: Members of the same family or household means persons related by consanguinity or affinity, persons legally married, persons formerly married, persons with a child in common, or persons in an intimate relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Mandatory arrest for protective order violations, including misdemeanors not witnessed by officer.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers, teachers, social workers, law enforcement
primary_statute_citation: N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 812, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 530.11
notable_provisions: No standalone DV crime - charged as family offenses (assault, menacing, stalking, etc.). Aggravated family offense (Class E felony) for repeat offenders. Orders up to 2-5 years.
recent_changes: 2024: Melanie's Law expands protective orders to all family members. Clean Slate Act effective Nov 2024.

relationship_definition: Current or former spouses, persons of opposite sex who live together or have lived together, parents and children, persons of opposite sex who are in a dating relationship or have been in such a relationship, persons who have a child in common. NOTE: Courts have extended protections to same-sex relationships following Obergefell.
arrest_policy_notes: North Carolina does NOT have mandatory arrest for DV. Officers have discretion under N.C.G.S. § 15A-401. May arrest without warrant if probable cause exists for felony or certain misdemeanors. No specific primary/dominant aggressor statute.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard healthcare mandatory reporters for child/elder abuse
primary_statute_citation: N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-32.5 (Domestic Violence offense); § 50B-1 et seq. (Domestic Violence Chapter); § 14-269.8 (Firearms prohibition)
notable_provisions: 2023: New standalone DV crime created (§ 14-32.5) - Class A1 misdemeanor (up to 150 days). Previously DV prosecuted under assault statutes. DVPO violations: first offense Class A1 misdemeanor, third offense Class H felony. 48-hour domestic hold (cooling-off period) for DV arrests. Assault on female by male 18+ is separate Class A1 misdemeanor. Stalking with DVPO violation is Class H felony.
recent_changes: 2023: N.C. General Assembly enacted new standalone domestic violence crime (§ 14-32.5). This creates specific DV offense rather than relying solely on assault statutes. Courts have extended Chapter 50B protections to same-sex couples.

relationship_definition: Spouse, former spouse, parent, child, person related by blood or marriage, any individual presently residing together or who has resided together in past, persons who are in a dating or engagement relationship, persons who have a child in common regardless of marriage.
arrest_policy_notes: North Dakota has PREFERRED ARREST policy. Under N.D.C.C. § 14-07.1-11, if officer has probable cause to believe DV occurred (felony or misdemeanor, in or out of presence), officer SHALL PRESUME arrest is appropriate response. Must determine predominant aggressor considering: comparative injuries, history of DV, likelihood of future harm. 12-hour window from probable cause establishment.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare providers report criminally injurious conduct; counselors have privilege exceptions
primary_statute_citation: N.D. Cent. Code § 14-07.1-01 et seq. (Domestic Violence Chapter); § 12.1-17-01 (Simple Assault); § 12.1-17-01.1 (Aggravated Assault)
notable_provisions: DVPO violation: first offense Class A misdemeanor, subsequent Class C felony. Stalking DVPO violation is Class C felony. GPS monitoring available for pretrial release. State presumes not in child best interest to place with parent with history of DV. No-contact presumption pending judicial review. Mandatory counseling for DV convictions.
recent_changes: 2023: Updated DVPO statute to address stalking within protective orders (effective Aug 1, 2023). Effective after December 31, 2025: new provisions regarding civil protection orders under Chapter 14-07.7. False allegation provisions requiring payment of court costs/attorney fees if allegation found false and not in good faith.

relationship_definition: Spouse, former spouse, person living as spouse (cohabitants), parent, child, foster parent, person related by blood or marriage to offender, parent or child of person living as spouse, person who has child in common with offender.
arrest_policy_notes: Ohio has PREFERRED ARREST (not mandatory). Under ORC § 2935.032, arrest is preferred response for felonious assault DV. For felonious assault involving serious injury or weapon, arrest is MANDATORY. Must determine primary physical aggressor considering: comparative severity of injuries, history of DV, prior acts by aggressor. Cannot release defendant until judge/magistrate review under ORC § 2919.251.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse; DV-specific reporting varies
primary_statute_citation: Ohio Rev. Code § 2919.25 (Domestic Violence); § 2919.26 (Temporary Protection Orders); § 3113.31 (Civil Protection Orders); § 2923.13 (Firearms disability)
notable_provisions: First offense threats: M4. First offense physical harm: M1 (up to 180 days). Prior DV conviction: F4 (6-18 months). Two+ priors: F3 (9-36 months prison presumption). Pregnant victim enhancement. TPO (criminal) vs CPO (civil) available. Federal firearm prohibition applies. Felony violence conviction bars firearm possession under state law. Battered woman syndrome evidence admissible. 2024: Marital rape made explicit crime.
recent_changes: 2024: Ohio Legislature made marital rape explicitly a crime (April 24, 2024). Airtag stalking now criminalized. DV misdemeanor 4th degree no longer eligible for sealing/expungement. Ongoing efforts to strengthen protections and close loopholes.

relationship_definition: Current or former spouse, present spouse of former spouse, parents (including foster), former spouse of parent, child (including foster/adopted), person otherwise related by blood or marriage, person with whom defendant is/was in dating relationship, person living in same household, person who formerly lived in same household, person who is parent of defendant child.
arrest_policy_notes: Oklahoma does NOT have mandatory arrest. Under 22 O.S. § 60.16, warrantless arrest PERMITTED (not required) if officer has probable cause person committed DV within preceding 72 hours. Arrest strongly encouraged. 72-hour cooling-off period before release. 12-hour minimum hold before bond consideration. No specific dominant aggressor statute but officers encouraged to identify primary aggressor.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Healthcare professionals report if criminally injurious; referral to DV services required
primary_statute_citation: Okla. Stat. tit. 21 § 644 (Domestic Abuse); § 644.1 (Prior Pattern); tit. 22 § 60.1 et seq. (VPO); § 60.16 (Arrest procedures)
notable_provisions: First offense: M (up to 1 year, $5,000). In presence of child: mandatory 6 months minimum first offense, 1 year minimum second. Strangulation: felony up to 3 years. Prior pattern (3+ incidents): F up to 10 years. Pregnant victim: F first offense (up to 5 years), subsequent up to 10 or 20 years if injury to fetus. VPO violation: M first, F repeat. Weapons seizure and forfeiture available. No-drop prosecution policies common.
recent_changes: 2024: Statute updated (Laws 2024, c. 38) continuing strengthening of DV provisions. Prior pattern of physical abuse felony enhancement. Enhanced penalties for assault on pregnant woman. Victim protective orders (VPO) strengthened. GPS monitoring available for release conditions.

relationship_definition: Spouses, former spouses, adult persons related by blood, marriage, or adoption, persons cohabiting or who have cohabited, persons who have been involved in a sexually intimate relationship within past two years, unmarried parents of minor child.
arrest_policy_notes: Oregon has MANDATORY ARREST. Under ORS 133.055(2)(a), when officer responds to domestic disturbance and has probable cause to believe assault occurred or person placed another in fear of imminent serious physical injury, officer SHALL arrest and take into custody. Applies to family/household members per ORS 107.705. Officer must determine assailant/potential assailant considering: comparative injuries, history of DV, self-defense factors. Not required to arrest both parties.
mandatory_reporter_categories: No mandatory DV reporting for healthcare; child abuse reporting applies
primary_statute_citation: ORS 107.700-107.735 (FAPA - Family Abuse Prevention Act); ORS 133.055 (Mandatory Arrest); ORS 163.160 (Assault IV); ORS 163.187 (Strangulation)
notable_provisions: FAPA restraining order: 1 year, renewable. No specific DV crime - uses assault degrees with DV designation. Assault IV to Assault I range. DV designation triggers: mandatory no-contact pretrial, enhanced sentencing considerations, future charging implications. Mandatory arrest since responding to DV call. Releasing officer must contact victim before release. Extreme Risk Protection Orders (red flag law) available. Some counties offer DV deferred sentencing programs.
recent_changes: Oregon continues strengthening DV response. FAPA provides civil protection separate from criminal process. Strangulation specifically criminalized (ORS 163.187). Mandatory arrest policy among strictest in nation. Recent focus on improving victim notification and services coordination.

relationship_definition: Spouses or persons who have been spouses, persons living as spouses or who lived as spouses, parents and children, other persons related by consanguinity or affinity, current or former sexual or intimate partners, persons who share biological parenthood.
arrest_policy_notes: Pennsylvania has MANDATORY ARREST for PFA (Protection From Abuse) violations under 23 Pa.C.S. § 6113. For other DV offenses, officers MAY arrest with probable cause without warrant under 18 Pa.C.S. § 2711. If weapon used, officer must seize weapons. Cannot release defendant until judge appearance. Judge must consider victim risk before bail release. Strong pro-arrest policy though not strictly mandatory for all DV.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Confidential communications privilege for DV counselors; standard mandatory reporters
primary_statute_citation: 23 Pa.C.S. § 6101 et seq. (Protection From Abuse Act); 18 Pa.C.S. § 2701-2702 (Assault); § 2711 (Probable cause arrest DV); § 6105 (Firearms prohibition)
notable_provisions: PFA orders available (no criminal charge required). Simple assault: M2. Aggravated assault: F1 or F2. Strangulation: F2. PFA violation: indirect criminal contempt up to 6 months, direct contempt. DV against child under 6: enhanced assault. Statewide PFA registry maintained by PA State Police. Federal and state firearm prohibitions apply. NIBRS reporting required.
recent_changes: Ongoing strengthening of PFA Act provisions. Statewide registry improvements. Enhanced training requirements for law enforcement. Confidential communications privilege for DV counselors/advocates. Continued focus on coordinated community response.

relationship_definition: Spouses, former spouses, adult persons related by blood or marriage, persons who are presently residing together or who have resided together in past 3 years, persons who have child in common, persons who are or have been in substantive dating or engagement relationship within past year.
arrest_policy_notes: Rhode Island has MANDATORY ARREST under R.I.G.L. § 12-29-3 when officer has probable cause to believe: assault resulted in bodily injury, deadly weapon used/threatened, or protective order violated. Must determine primary physical aggressor. Cannot release on bail until court appearance. No-contact order MANDATORY at arraignment for DV charges.
mandatory_reporter_categories: No specific mandatory DV reporting; standard child/elder abuse reporting
primary_statute_citation: R.I. Gen. Laws § 12-29-1 et seq. (Domestic Violence Prevention Act); § 15-15-1 et seq. (Domestic Abuse - Family Court); § 11-47-5 et seq. (Firearms)
notable_provisions: First offense: up to 1 year, Batterers Intervention Program (BIP), $125 assessment. Second offense: mandatory 10 days minimum. Third+: F, 1-10 years mandatory minimum. Firearm surrender within 24 hours of prohibition. Proof of surrender form required. DV misdemeanor bars firearms (state and federal). Five-year waiting period before petition to restore rights for certain misdemeanors. Extreme Risk Protection Orders available.
recent_changes: 2017: Protect Rhode Island Families Act significantly strengthened firearm provisions - mandatory surrender for all final protection orders. Ongoing improvements to enforcement and verification of firearm surrender compliance. Courts required to ensure relinquishment.

relationship_definition: Spouse, former spouse, persons who have child in common, male and female who are cohabiting or formerly cohabited. NOTE: 2017 SC Supreme Court (Jane Doe v. State) held male/female language cannot be used to deny protection to same-sex relationships.
arrest_policy_notes: South Carolina does NOT have mandatory arrest. Under S.C. Code § 16-25-70, officers MAY arrest without warrant with probable cause. Must determine primary physical aggressor considering: comparative injuries, fear of injury, history of DV, prior complaints. Cannot arrest non-aggressor if primary aggressor identified. Dual arrest discouraged.
firearm_prohibition_duration: lifetime for DVHAN/felony; 10 years for F1
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse; no specific DV healthcare mandate
primary_statute_citation: S.C. Code § 16-25-10 et seq. (Domestic Violence); § 16-25-65 (DVHAN); § 16-25-70 (Arrest); § 20-4-10 et seq. (Protection from Domestic Abuse Act); § 16-25-30 (Firearms)
notable_provisions: Four degrees: DV 3rd (M, up to 90 days, $1,000-$2,500). DV 2nd (M, up to 3 years, $2,500-$5,000) - moderate bodily injury. DV 1st (F, up to 10 years) - great bodily injury, 3rd offense in 10 years, firearm used, PO violation with DV2. DVHAN (F, up to 20 years) - extreme indifference to human life. DVHAN/felony: lifetime firearm prohibition. DV1: 10-year firearm prohibition. 85% no-parole for DVHAN sentences.
recent_changes: 2015: Major DV law overhaul (Act No. 58) creating four-tier system with enhanced penalties. 2017: SC Supreme Court extended protections to same-sex couples. Domestic Violence Fatality Review Committees established. Address Confidentiality Program enacted (2024).

relationship_definition: Spouse, former spouse, persons who reside or have resided in same household, persons who have child in common, persons who are in dating relationship or have been in such relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: South Dakota has MANDATORY ARREST. Under SDCL § 25-10-36, if officer has probable cause to believe person committed domestic abuse, officer SHALL arrest. Must determine predominant aggressor considering: comparative injuries, serious threats creating fear, history of DV. DV indicator placed in arrest file. Cannot release until judicial determination of bond/conditions.
firearm_prohibition_duration: 1 year for misdemeanor DV; 15 years for felony
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse
primary_statute_citation: S.D. Codified Laws § 25-10-1 et seq. (Domestic Abuse); § 22-19A-1 et seq. (Stalking); § 25-10-36 (Mandatory Arrest); § 22-14-24 (Firearms)
notable_provisions: No specific DV crime - domestic abuse indicator added to offense file triggering special provisions. Simple assault: M, 1 year, $2,000. Aggravated assault: F various classes. PO violation: M1, F6 if assault/stalking. Third+ PO violation in 10 years: F4, F5, or F6 based on priors. No-contact order mandatory as bond condition (SDCL 25-10-23). Counseling required for probation. Firearm prohibition: 1 year for misdemeanor, 15 years for felony.
recent_changes: Ongoing improvements to domestic abuse response. Domestic abuse indicator system ensures tracking across incidents. Mandatory arrest policy strongly enforced. Focus on predominant aggressor determination to prevent dual arrests.

relationship_definition: Adults or minors who are current or former spouses, live together or have lived together, are dating or have dated, have had sexual relations, are related by blood or adoption, are related or were formerly related by marriage, adult or minor children of person in such relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Tennessee has PREFERRED ARREST policy. Under T.C.A. § 36-3-619, if officer has probable cause to believe person committed crime involving domestic abuse, preferred response is arrest. Must try to determine primary aggressor if both parties complain. Officer shall not dismiss as two-party guilt. Cannot release until bond hearing. No-contact as condition of release.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters; healthcare referral to DV services encouraged
primary_statute_citation: T.C.A. § 39-13-111 (Domestic Assault); § 36-3-601 et seq. (Domestic Abuse/Orders of Protection); § 39-17-1307 (Firearms)
notable_provisions: Domestic assault: Class A M (up to 11 months 29 days). Aggravated domestic assault: Class C F (3-15 years). Prior DV conviction enhances penalties. Bodily injury enhancement. Order of Protection violation: Class A M, Class E F if assault during violation. Strangulation: F. 2021: Abrials Law (Keeping Children Safe from Family Violence Act) - custody/visitation factors. Coercive control increasingly recognized.
recent_changes: 2021: Abrials Law enacted addressing family violence in custody proceedings. Focus on children witnessing DV. Enhanced training for judges handling DV cases. Continued strengthening of protection order enforcement. Primary aggressor protocols emphasized.

relationship_definition: Member of family or household: individuals related by blood, affinity, or marriage, former spouses, parents of same child, foster child and foster parent, current or former household members, individuals in dating relationship (current or former).
arrest_policy_notes: Texas does NOT have mandatory arrest for family violence. Under Tex. Code Crim. Proc. Art. 5.04, officers primary duty is to protect victim and enforce law. May arrest without warrant with probable cause. Must stay on scene as long as necessary to protect victim. Emergency Protective Order MANDATORY if arrest for offense involving serious bodily injury or deadly weapon. No specific primary aggressor statute.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse
primary_statute_citation: Tex. Penal Code § 22.01 (Assault); § 25.11 (Continuous Violence Against Family); Tex. Family Code § 71.004 (Family Violence definition); Tex. Code Crim. Proc. Art. 5 (Family Violence Prevention)
notable_provisions: Domestic assault threats: Class C M ($500 fine). Bodily injury: Class A M (1 year, $4,000). Prior conviction/strangulation: F3 (2-10 years). Continuous violence (2+ assaults in 12 months): F3. Aggravated domestic assault (serious injury/weapon): F1 or F2 (5-99 years or life). Violation of protective order: Class A M, F3 if repeat or assault during violation. Batterers Intervention and Prevention Program (BIPP) often ordered.
recent_changes: Continuous Violence Against Family law allows prosecution for pattern without prior convictions. Enhanced focus on strangulation cases. Family Violence Protection Team in major jurisdictions. Emergency Protective Orders expanded. No-drop prosecution policies common in DA offices.

relationship_definition: Spouse, former spouse, cohabitant (unrelated adult living in same residence or who lived together within past year), person with whom respondent has child, parent, child, stepchild, grandparent, grandchild, sibling, person in dating relationship with respondent.
arrest_policy_notes: Utah has MANDATORY ARREST/CITATION policy. Under Utah Code § 77-36-2.2, if officer has probable cause to believe DV occurred, officer shall arrest or issue citation. MUST arrest (no citation option) if: victim likely to remain in danger, serious injury caused, dangerous weapon used. Must attempt to determine primary aggressor. Jail release agreement or judicial appearance required before release.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse; healthcare encouraged to provide DV resources
primary_statute_citation: Utah Code § 77-36-1 et seq. (Cohabitant Abuse Procedures); § 78B-7-101 et seq. (Protective Orders); § 76-5-102 et seq. (Assault)
notable_provisions: DV assault: Class B M (6 months). Class A M if injury or prior conviction. Third offense in 5 years: F3. Aggravated assault/DV: F3 or F2. Protective order violation: Class A M, F3 if third+ in 5 years. Cohabitant protective order separate from criminal case. Sentencing protective order can be imposed upon conviction. Electronic monitoring available. Mandatory counseling for DV probation.
recent_changes: Utah continues strengthening DV response. Emphasis on mandatory arrest with limited citation alternative for safety concerns. Cohabitant abuse procedures specifically address DV. Sentencing protective orders provide ongoing protection post-conviction.

relationship_definition: Family members: spouses, former spouses, parents, children, persons related by blood or marriage. Household members: persons who reside or have resided together.
arrest_policy_notes: Vermont has OFFICER DISCRETION arrest policy. Under Vt. R. Crim. P. Rule 3, officer MAY arrest without warrant if probable cause to believe person committed assault against family/household member, even if not in presence. Same for relief from abuse order violations. No mandatory arrest statute. Conditions of release may include no contact, no firearms, no alcohol/drugs.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse
primary_statute_citation: 13 V.S.A. § 1041-1044 (Domestic Assault); 15 V.S.A. § 1101 et seq. (Abuse Prevention); 13 V.S.A. § 4017 (Firearms)
notable_provisions: Domestic assault: up to 18 months, $5,000. Second offense: up to 3 years. Aggravated domestic assault: up to 15 years (serious injury, weapon, strangulation, repeat). Relief from abuse order violation: up to 1 year, $5,000. Stalking: up to 2 years. Aggravated stalking: up to 5 years. Firearms removed at arrest if necessary. Violent crime conviction bars firearm possession (up to 2 years, $1,000 for violation).
recent_changes: Vermont focuses on graduated penalties for repeat offenses. Aggravated domestic assault captures most serious cases. Relief from abuse orders available through civil process. Strong protections for firearms removal. Coordinated community response approach.

relationship_definition: Family or household member: spouse, former spouse, parents, stepparents, children, stepchildren, siblings, half-siblings, grandparents, grandchildren, in-laws, persons who cohabit or have cohabited within past 12 months and their children, persons who have child in common.
arrest_policy_notes: Virginia has SHALL ARREST for physical aggression. Under Va. Code § 19.2-81.3, if officer has probable cause to believe assault/battery occurred against family/household member or protective order violated, officer MAY make warrantless arrest. If physical aggression occurred, officer MUST arrest. Must also petition for Emergency Protective Order if danger continues.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse
primary_statute_citation: Va. Code § 18.2-57.2 (Assault/Battery Family Member); § 16.1-253.1 et seq. (Protective Orders); § 19.2-81.3 (Arrest); § 18.2-308.1:4 (Firearms)
notable_provisions: Assault on family member: Class 1 M (up to 12 months, $2,500). Third offense in 20 years: Class 6 F (1-5 years). Strangulation: Class 6 F. PO violation: Class 1 M, mandatory 60 days for second in 5 years, Class 6 F with 6 months mandatory for third in 20 years. Armed PO violation: Class 6 F. EPO issued at every DV arrest (72 hours). Preliminary PO extends protection. Final PO up to 2 years.
recent_changes: 2024: Updates to protective order violation penalties (cc. 108, 118). EPO automatically issued with DV arrest. Strong emphasis on emergency protection. Graduated penalties for repeat violations. Strangulation specifically criminalized as felony.

relationship_definition: Family or household members: spouses, former spouses, persons who have child in common, adult persons related by blood or marriage, adult persons currently residing or who have resided together, persons 16 or older in dating relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Washington has MANDATORY ARREST. Under RCW 10.31.100(2)(d), if officer has probable cause person 18+ assaulted family/household member within preceding 4 hours, SHALL arrest if: felonious assault with bodily injury, OR assault with bodily injury (observable or not), OR action intended to cause fear of imminent serious injury/death. Must determine primary physical aggressor considering: RCW 10.99.010 intent to protect victims, extent of injuries, history of DV/pattern of abuse. Mandatory arrest also for protection order violations.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters; DV advocates have privilege
primary_statute_citation: RCW 10.99 (Domestic Violence Official Response); RCW 10.31.100 (Arrest); RCW 26.50 (Domestic Violence Prevention); RCW 9.41.800 (Firearms Surrender)
notable_provisions: Assault 4 (DV): gross M (364 days). Assault 2 (DV): Class B F (10 years). No-contact order mandatory at first appearance. Defendant appears within 1 judicial day. Firearm surrender within 24 hours of order. 12-month DV Batterers Treatment Program. Loss of firearm rights can be permanent. Protection order violation: gross M, F if repeat. Extreme Risk Protection Orders available. Among nations strictest DV laws.
recent_changes: Washington continues having among strictest DV laws nationally. 4-hour mandatory arrest window. Strong firearm surrender requirements with 24-hour deadline. No-contact orders automatic. RCW 9.41.800 updated to strengthen firearms provisions. Legislature regularly updates to strengthen protections.

relationship_definition: Family or household members: persons who are or were married, persons living together as spouses or who formerly lived together as spouses, parents, children, stepparents, stepchildren, siblings, half-siblings, grandparents, grandchildren, persons presently residing or who formerly resided together, persons who have child in common, persons who have had intimate partner relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: West Virginia has MANDATORY ARREST for witnessed DV and protective order violations. Under W.Va. Code § 48-27-1002, officer who witnesses DV or DVPO violation SHALL arrest. For unwitnessed DV, MAY arrest with probable cause without warrant. If weapon threatened or used, SHALL seize weapon. Must determine predominant aggressor. No-contact order as bail condition required for continued safety threat.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse; adult protective services for vulnerable adults
primary_statute_citation: W.Va. Code § 61-2-28 (Domestic Violence - Criminal Acts); § 48-27-101 et seq. (Prevention and Treatment of Domestic Violence); § 61-7-7 (Firearms)
notable_provisions: Domestic battery: M (24 hours-12 months for first, 30 days-1 year for second, 60 days-1 year for third within 10 years). Domestic assault: M (up to 6 months). Felony DV battery: 1-5 years if strangulation, 2-10 years if serious injury. Malicious assault: F (2-10 years). DVPO violation: M, F for repeat. DVPO automatically requires firearm prohibition. Sexual assault by family member: F (10-25 years).
recent_changes: West Virginia strengthened DV laws with mandatory arrest for witnessed offenses. DVPO automatically includes firearm prohibition. Graduated penalties for repeat offenses. Strangulation treated as felony. Ongoing focus on enforcement and victim services coordination.

relationship_definition: Spouse, former spouse, adult person residing or formerly residing with defendant, adult person with whom defendant has child in common, adult person in dating relationship with defendant.
arrest_policy_notes: Wisconsin has PRO-ARREST policy. Under Wis. Stat. § 968.075, unless no basis for arrest exists, officer SHALL arrest when reasonable grounds to believe person committing/committed DV. Officer need not arrest if no reasonable grounds. Must determine predominant aggressor considering: history, statements, severity of injuries, likelihood of future violence, self-defense. 72-hour no-contact period. Cannot release until judicial appearance.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse; healthcare encouraged to provide DV resources
primary_statute_citation: Wis. Stat. § 968.075 (Domestic Abuse Incidents); § 813.12 (Domestic Abuse Restraining Orders); § 940.19 et seq. (Battery); § 941.29 (Firearms)
notable_provisions: Battery: Class A M (9 months). Substantial battery: Class I F (3.5 years). Aggravated battery: Class H F (6 years). DV enhancer increases maximum penalty. Domestic abuse injunction violation: Class A M, $10,000 fine. 72-hour no-contact mandatory. Counseling or treatment assessment required. Firearm prohibition during injunction. Prohibited person for felony conviction.
recent_changes: Wisconsin pro-arrest policy is strong but not absolute mandatory arrest. Focus on predominant aggressor determination. 72-hour no-contact period provides immediate protection. DV surcharge on penalties. Treatment and batterers intervention programs available.

relationship_definition: Household members: persons who reside together or have resided together, persons who are or were in dating relationship, persons who have child in common, persons related by blood or marriage, persons who are or were in intimate relationship.
arrest_policy_notes: Wyoming has OFFICER DISCRETION arrest policy. Under Wyo. Stat. § 7-20-102, officer MAY arrest without warrant if probable cause to believe person committed domestic abuse (misdemeanor or felony). No mandatory arrest statute. Officer should consider: comparative injuries, history, self-defense, nature of conduct. No specific predominant aggressor statute but best practices encourage determination.
mandatory_reporter_categories: Standard mandatory reporters for child abuse
primary_statute_citation: Wyo. Stat. § 6-2-501 et seq. (Assault and Battery); § 35-21-101 et seq. (Domestic Violence Protection); § 7-20-102 (Arrest); § 6-8-102 (Firearms)
notable_provisions: Simple assault: M (up to 6 months, $750). Battery: M (up to 6 months, $750). Aggravated assault: F (up to 10 years). Domestic battery first: M (up to 6 months). Domestic battery with prior: M (up to 1 year). Third+ domestic battery in 5 years: F (up to 5 years). Order of protection violation: M first, F if repeat. Firearm restriction available as bail/release condition. Felony conviction bars firearms.
recent_changes: Wyoming relies on general assault/battery statutes with domestic battery enhancements for repeat offenders. Order of protection system provides civil remedy. Ongoing efforts to improve DV response training for law enforcement. No red flag/ERPO law currently.
